bibl.title: Were Late Roman and Byzantine Economies Market Economies? A Comparative Look at Historiography.
bibl.note: Paper delivered at the Spring Symposium held at Dumbarton Oaks, 2-4 May 2008. - The criteria for a market economy. - Continuity and change in economic structures and models from the later fourth through the ninth century. - The complementary interplay of town and country in the network of exchanges, and the question of the consumer city. - Concluding remarks.
bibl.seg: Jean-Michel Carrié, Were Late Roman and Byzantine Economies Market Economies? A Comparative Look at Historiography.
Cécile Morrisson (ed.), Trade and Markets in Byzantium = Dumbarton Oaks Byzantine Symposia and Colloquia (Washington, D.C., 2012) pp. 13-26.

Paper delivered at the Spring Symposium held at Dumbarton Oaks, 2-4 May 2008. - The criteria for a market economy. - Continuity and change in economic structures and models from the later fourth through the ninth century. - The complementary interplay of town and country in the network of exchanges, and the question of the consumer city. - Concluding remarks.
